replies.commentBody:
Come November it'll be the American voters who'll be trashing Trump.

Let's see, Barack Obama, continuously trashed by the Republicans and the right-wing media, twice the choice of an actual majority of those voting...

Say Mark, you haven't been trashing the people's choice, have you?

comments.commentBody:
By trashing Trump, the elites in America and the presstitute media are trashing a majority of American Republicans and Independents (and even many Democrats).

This issue is NOT about Trump. It is about whether or not every day Americans can decide for themselves to vote for the candidate THEY want, or whether the elites and their phony media get to foist another puppet on us. If it wasn't Trump it might be someone else.

We've had enough of the elites telling us who to vote for. Public servants should not be living better than 90% of us from “investments”. We're voting for Trump, come hell or high water.

Love the Trump bashers, like they know him so well. Sure he needs to tone it down, but he had to generate a wave. I’d say Dr. Ben Carson, Mark Cuban, Tom Brady, Mike Ditka, Terrell Owens, Chuck Yeager, etc that have actually spoken to and support him, know Trump better than us TV viewers. And that is what scares the hell out of the GOP Establishment and Hillary Clinton. They know him unlike us. Time to right the wrongs.

#TRUMP2016

replies.commentBody: I am sure congress would try. They haven't represent the American people for a while.

comments.commentBody:
Two questions: If Trump won the nomination, and then the presidency, how long would it take Congress to impeach him, and on what grounds?
Considering that, who would his vice president be?

"It's the Economy Stupid"

What rang true in 1992, rings true now. The "Great Recession" and the trillions we spent failed to bring enough economic change or increase in Real Jobs or Real help. Frankly, everyone is looking for an economic "Savior". That has given us the rise of Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump. I'm ok with both because both make Washington nervous.

American companies were supposed to pay real living wages, have real benefits (like Good Medical and Good Pension Plans). That hasn't happened in decades. Until we buy what we make her in America, that won't happen.

replies.commentBody:
Tuvw Xyz--
"Closest living relative"? Lol....that is really good!
I'm stealing that one immediately, if not sooner.

comments.commentBody:
In my apolitical opinion, neither Trump nor Clinton is qualified to rule the US for a single hour, to say nothing of the four years.

I am considering to write-in in November "the living closest kin of" either Theodore Roosevelt or Lincoln. Too bad that the US line of the Bonapartes became extinct in 1919: a President Bonaparte would have looked good in history books.

replies.commentBody: The only two candidates that haven't have a track record of death and destruction are Trump and Sanders. Trump is an isolationist and Sanders a communist, they would keep America out of foreign war. Hillary is a tier 1 warmonger on the order of Cheney. I fully expect her to bomb Syria, Iran and Yemen if elected.

Ah yes, Donald Trump, the choice of progressives! What universe does this make sense in?

For the last seven years we've seen the spectacle of the Republicans basically saying "if we can't run the country we'll do whatever we can to drag it down."

I do not believe that any substantial number of Bernie's supporters will take such a nihilistic course.

comments.commentBody: Don't forget the "Anybody but Hillary" crowd.  Unfortunately for them, Bernie has no chance after yesterday.    Assuming that the Trump train continues picking up steam, and he gets the nomination, many Bernie supporters will wind up voting for Trump in the general election.

replies.commentBody:
fran--
I'm sorry, but exactly when was the GOP "the party of humility and humanity"?

comments.commentBody:
I support the GOP, but if Trump extorts votes with the threat of riots like he did today, I have lost faith and will gladly switch affiliations.

The GOP was once the party of humility and humanity - this is a test of that humanity, and MILLIONS of us are standing by to move for the sake of the nation.

replies.commentBody:
Guess you never heard of Teddy Roosevelt and FDR. A strong president keeps congress, his cabinet and special interest groups in check by being the baddest wolf in the pack. A weak president let congress, cabinet and special interest run wild and hamper policy making.

Obama is a great guy. I'd love for him to be my professor but he is weak. Hillary, Kerry, congress, CIA, NSA, the Pentagon are walking all over him.

comments.commentBody:
He can do it the same way he's been doing it.

Threats, bribes, coercion. Or as he calls it - doing great deals.

Since December, I have been predicting -- "It will be Hillary against Cruz and Hillary will win." This prediction is simply looking better and better.

But that isn't what is interesting to me right now. I've been reflectly today on why I made that prediction and why it's coming true. The answer I have arrived at is, "A deep and abiding cynicism."

I deeply believe that things are really as bad as they seem ... probably worse. An optimist is someone who doesn't comprehend the gravity of the situation. The only philosophy that makes sense today is to embrace "the euphoria of despair". When there is absolutely, positively no hope whatsoever, then go out like the grasshopper in the fable, not the ant. Eat, drink, and make merry (or Mary, if she's up for it).

"The Virtue of Ignorance," by Donald J. Trump.  A primer on how to gain political acceptance by appealing to the least knowledgeable with proposals that have little or no likelihood of making their lives better but allow them the satisfaction of attacking other people whom Trump cons them into believing are to blame for whatever makes them unhappy.

replies.commentBody: That would require him to spend his money on something, which he won't do.  He has basically run his campaign for free through bombast that our right wing media feels it must cover.  If he doesn't get the Republican nomination, he won't run as an independent because, again, he would have to spend his own money.  And, by the way, the vast majority of his net worth is in his head.

Brilliant, but I'm more interested in who Trump choses as his VP candidate. And...I gotta ask, which Democrat would be idiot enough to run a third party campaign?

I'm fascinated to see which Republicans have committed to Trump. It is no easy thing to hook your star to an eccentric outsider who is 69. I can't help but noting Nicky Haley has not fallen under the Trump crescent. And...I believe Marco Rubio committed political suicide, not when Chris Christie eviscerated him during a National Debate, but when Rubio attempted to be as rude and challenging as Trump on National TV. Why would a Democrat sign up for the Trump show?

Caveat--I didn't see the Trump phenomena coming...So, I have no right to dispute Tim's prediction. In fact, I appreciate someone with a new read on the voting public. No one else has got it right. Way to go Tim. Hope you're wrong.

comments.commentBody: Trump will get a third party democrat to run against Hillary and then run away with the election. TRUMP 2016

replies.commentBody: Very possible that the House will choose the next President!  With three possible candidates, no one might get enough electoral college votes to win outright, we would have the Republican controlled House choose the President!!
Hadn't thought of that.  Yikes!

comments.commentBody:
Trouble ahead for BOTH parties in my opinion as for first time in
US political history leading GOP & Democratic winners for
2016 are equally disliked by the electorate. A third party
would derail both. Therefore, either party must get a strong
running mate for VP (many VPs & that is confirmed in
history have become Presidents.) A puzzle yet to be solved
is it not?

replies.commentBody:
Are you living in a fairytale?
After innumerable failed wars, a monstrous public debt, a huge income inequality, and a suicidal immigration policy, America is anything but great, and we see the results: China (or the North-East-Asia region) will soon supplant America (or the entire Western World), becoming the new hub of civilization.
Why is that? There's a reason is Africa is the starving continent, while Europe and North-East-Asia have always been the centers of civilization. We are the reflection of our countries, and the alteration of the demographics of one particular country will inevitably result in a total transformation. Could you imagine if the high IQ Japanese people were to turn their country into Zimbawe or Uganda; Japan will no longer be one of the most advanced places on earth.

comments.commentBody: After being unable to avert my gaze from the train wreck that is the Donald Trump campaign, I don't know why it took me so long to understand that his slogan, "Make America Great Again," is not what it's really about. Trump, by his own words and deeds, has no interest in making a country which is already great,  "great again." What that slogan is really saying is that Trump, and the people who support him, only wants to make America "white" again. Trump supporters have had a hard time over the last seven years dealing with, as a now former friend of mine once said to me, "having a black man (although that wasn't the word he used) in OUR White House." That's the problem with these people. They can't abide the fact that a person from a race of people they look down on is leading America in a very positive and respectful way. Ideology doesn't matter. I'm 70 years old, and I don't remember ever seeing a President of the United States dealt with by the opposition in such a contemptible and disgraceful way as Mr. Obama has been since his first day in office. These people, the greatest threat to America, don't want to do anything but make America white again. As Joseph Welsh said to Sen. Joseph McCarthy, "Have you no decency, sir? Have you no decency?" I'm afraid these people, and their Fuhrer, do not.

replies.commentBody: "Public Discourse" on the GOP side has entered the locker room of the junior varsity football team.
@Doctor. You give the GOP too much credit.

comments.commentBody:
Having just watched President Obama's graceful but powerful nomination of Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court brings home a stark contradiction in contemporary American political life. That the voting public could choose the profane, rudely delivered narrative of "telling it like it isn't" over the grace of the President's courteous constructivism speaks volumes about what we have become as a people.

Happily, the narrative has not yet reached its final chapter. We might be better than we seem at this baleful moment of public discourse.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

I'm not so sure that PA, CT, DE, RI and NY are "clearly" in Trump's pocket. Kasich should have a good chance in these. It looks like Rubio voters broke toward Kasich, which helps him. Kasich could still chalk up some big wins.

On the other side, while a solidly blue state, Republicans in CA, especially in the Central Valley and San Diego, can be quite conservative and run toward the red-neck side of things--Trump territory. Same with WA and OR. Evangelical Idaho is likely good for Cruz, but the rest he'll get will be small states.

The bigger question is whether Republican voters will wake up to the fact that they have a bona fide fascist leading their party -- and if, realizing this, they will embrace it or reject it.

replies.commentBody: Why the Illinois National Guard?
I think the Republican convention must be in Chicago?
Cleveland,  Ohio.

comments.commentBody:
I'm not sure what is more frightening...Trump's call to arms (really!?!) for his followers to fight against a brokered convention, or the prospect of a President Trump. Either way, the Illinois National Guard should stand ready.

The mind boggles.

replies.commentBody: Since Rubio is now out of the contest does this even matter anymore?

Trump has his Hawaii guys looking into it.

If Kasich becomes President, look for Donald to be on Fox and Friends calling for impeachment for 4 years.
Rubio dropped it. It shows that Kasich didn't even think he would be in this race that long.

comments.commentBody:
Heard last night on CNN that Rubio has an outstanding legal challenge to Kasich qualifying to be on PA's ballot. Rubio is challenging Kasich's 100 signatures just 100 over the required signatures needed to qualify to be on PA ballot.

Does anyone know anything about this?
Cruz cool show some patriotism and dump his constituents to Kasich.  That would divide into half for Trump and maybe half for Kasich.  Trump still wins all the way!
Is there any recent polling that backs up the idea that Trump is the favorite in states like NY, CT, and PA? It's hard for me to see Kasich not having a fighter's chance in the Mid-Atlantic states.

replies.commentBody: Relax.  He may be a mess, but even if he can win the fall election, we have a  few more checks and balances in our system than they used in the Third Reich.

William--
I do not believe that Trump is a racist, in the usual meaning of the word. He simply has a low opinion of almost everyone, especially anyone who is low on the economic totem pole. Trump would speak against any group that enters illegally, and arrives without money or marketable skills. He fits perfectly in the GOP. What is different is that he is arrogant enough to say what they all think. And his saying what he thinks is not a virtue.

comments.commentBody: There is only one word: frightening.  I was born after WWII, and had to understand the rise of Hitler through history books.  How could a modern society like Germany elevate a hateful psychotic monster to the highest office? I now feel I am living through the same nightmare in a country where the very notion of an autocratic leader was absurd.....till now.  Trump must be defeated.

replies.commentBody:
People who are voting for Trump are not people who remember Bush in a bad light. Besides, they are voting for who they believe is a strong, authoritarian, protective leader because they have been brainwashed, frankly, by irresponsible sensationalized news that the U.S. is under attack by any and all outsiders as well as moral degenerates like gays. This kind of reaction to the onslaught of fear/war-mongering could have been, as was by numerous social scientists, predicted.
Trump speaks in powerful, black and white terms to people who are convinced that the earth is shifting beneath their very feet and that there is danger around every corner. They are no less victims than those they hate in many ways. They have been the targets of unprecedented propaganda designed to convince them to allow big business to rape resources, lower their wages, and start wars, killing thousands, while they stand around waving little flags.

These voters feel that the establishment has failed them and they feel angry about many things, thus they are attracted to Trump!  Its more about the failure of the establishment to provide good jobs and wages than the race issue.

comments.commentBody:
What I don't get why Trump supports can't figure out just how dangerous a loose cannon in the White House would be.

Doesn't anyone remember BUSH, WMD, and a little war that we all would like to forget?

Ho! I get it! They HAVE forgotten the war and just how bad things can get due to a loose cannon like Bush or Trump.

replies.commentBody:
Correct, we also don't know who the delegates will devote their power to as well but I would say it's safe to say that he will get a strong following from them as well. That's if to say it gets to that point. Regardless, a brokered convention should guarantee the nomination. Anybody else who gets the nomination, the GOP will have open rioting in the streets thus officially ending the party and handing the white house over to the Hilda beast.

I don't think Cruz can win northern states or west coast states. I think MA and NV were proof-of-concept for this statement.

Trump vs. Hilary should be the battle. Trump will taunt, terrorize, provoke her in non stop attacks. He will bring up all her baggage and attack her 24/7. The news media has already started that for him. She will struggle to keep up with him, tears of training on proper Pc talk will hurt her this year. She won't recover in time during the electoral voting stage.

Trump vs. Hilary should be the battle. Trump will taunt, terrorize, provoke her in non stop attacks. He will bring up all her baggage and attack her 24/7. The news media has already started that for him. She will struggle to keep up with him,  years of training on proper Pc talk will hurt her this year. She will recover in time during the electoral voting stage but it will be to late .

Trump will win the states of the former confederacy, a few farming states and a few mining states. That's it. He'll lose the women's vote, the college educated, Latinos, African-Americans, Asian-Americans and anyone who has a relative with a physical handicap. He'll lose Republicans with money and education. Election night will be over by 11 PM.

comments.commentBody:
Trump is in better shape than that-

We don't know the final split from Illinois and Missouri but he probably needs closer to 500 than 600

Second, Arizona isn't a state that he's really struggling in. The only poll out has him up Arizona early voting has been going on for weeks now and Trump is probably getting all 58 delegates

Together that would reduce his need from 350 to less than 200

Given that its unlikely that Kaisich can meet the 8 state rule, Trump is likely to win a first ballot even if he's a few delegate short. Rubio's delegates are now released as well

replies.commentBody: He'll pick David Petraeus. Don't you watch "House of Cards"?

comments.commentBody:
If Trump has the delegates going into the convention, who would the GOP pick as VP candidate? It would be the kiss of death for either Kasich or Cruz. They'd likely need a woman. Recycle Sarah? Nikki Haley? Unlikely.

What a Trump candidacy in the general election will likely mean is broad losses by the GOP down the ballot. The balance of power in the senate will probably shift back to the democrats; not a bad result.

replies.commentBody: Reasons?
You do understand that Sanders is also in favor of PP and the right to choose? And frankly, I don't think Trump gets worked up about PP either.

comments.commentBody:
Good. If Sanders aint on the ticket I will happily vote for The Donald.

I'll be down there mixing the mortar for the wall and bringing the chain to lock up planned parenthoods doors.

We will never vote for her.

Trump is going to be the nominee.  He was always going to be the nominee since about November.  I can think of no other candidate in recent memory who has received the free press he has.  The question is, in a Hillary/Donald match-up who wins.  Many Dems claim they would not vote for Hillary.  Many GOP CLAIM they would not vote for Trump.  I don't believe any of those people.

For important issues, Trump is better than Cruz: health care, taxes, abortion, planned parenthood, social liberties.

Clinton is better on healthcare and global warming, truly important concerns. I actually think income inequality might be fixed better under Trump, because he is making that his main concern and it's and after thought for Clinton.

The Repulican stop-Trump campaign is run by pro big business and hedge fund types, very telling. They do not care about "racism", don't believe that!

Trump is a bit scary on foreign policy. Our establishment has made a big mess; people vote for Trump because he correctly points that out. But, he can't just pull jobs out of China, Mexico, etc., he will destabilize. He has to do it slowly. Likewise, total reversal on mideast: got to do it carefully. But we have to do it! One huge legacy of Trump: whoever gets elected has to address these issues.

There is no excellent choice this fall. I blame DNC and DWS.
